awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Increasing Understanding of 30-60 Sec Resolution Satellite Observations with Respect to Convective Initiation and Improving Microphysical Parameterizations
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States launched a new observational satellite in 2016 called the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite, commonly referred to as GEOS-16.  This satellite contains a package of instruments that greatly improves the remote sensing of clouds and lightning.  In this award, researchers will make use of the rapid scan features of GOES-16 to study physical processes occurring in cumulus clouds.  The research has the potential to improve short time-frame convective forecasts, which are of economic and public safety interest.  The project will also train the next generation of scientists, ensuring an educated and prepared workforce.

The research team will use new super rapid scan (SRS) observations from the GOES-16 Advanced Baseline Imager (ABI) to examine physical processes occurring in growing and mature convective clouds.  SRS observations will be combined with radar, lightning, and model data to address the two main questions of the research project:  1) How do we maximize the value of high-time frequency SRS cloud-sensitive IR observations for understanding physical processes occurring in cumulus clouds? and 2) How do we extend the use of SRS datasets in combination with radar and NWP data to obtain longer predictive lead times for convective storms?  The specific basic science research goals are to gain understanding about in-cloud processes, especially updraft magnitude, evolution and size, factors influencing parcel buoyancy, and hydrometeor fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcomes of this project are a deeper understanding of the physical processes occurring within convective clouds in weakly-forced environments and a detailed assessment of the ability of different parameterization schemes in high-resolution numerical weather prediction models to accurately predict their evolution. An initial set of model simulations showed that differences in the onset of convection, known as convective initiation (CI), and the subsequent evolution of the deep cumulus clouds were directly related to the production of large water droplets in the lower portion of the clouds. The liquid precipitation is lofted to higher altitudes within the clouds where it freezes into snow or graupel. The timing of the onset of ice production typically coincided with the onset of CI. Comparisons of the model simulations to geostationary satellite-derived cloud growth rates and cloud top phase helped identify which microphysics parameterization schemes produce too much cloud ice at the cloud top, thereby leading to faster cloud growth rates, as well as which schemes underpredict liquid precipitation and therefore have delayed CI onset.

A second set of model experiments showed that larger and longer lasting thunderstorms occurred over forested regions in the southeastern United States. By comparing CI characteristics between simulations employing different land surface models, it was found that latent and sensible heat fluxes at the land surface were important drivers of differences in CI onset and evolution. Large horizontal gradients in sensible heat flux between adjacent forested and grassland areas influenced the intensity of local mesoscale circulations. Larger gradients within these transition zones led to stronger vertical motion, increased intensity of updrafts in clouds, and aided in creating sustained upper-level ice in clouds; thus, sustaining convection beyond CI.

Broader impacts of the project include training the next generation of physical scientists through enhancements to undergraduate and graduate level courses and the mentorship of an early-career scientist who gained experience running high-resolution model simulations and evaluating the model results using satellite and radar observations. Project results were also disseminated to the community through their inclusion in three peer-reviewed journal articles and several presentations at conferences. New insights into convective cloud processes obtained during this project will also promote efforts to improve the ability of numerical weather prediction models to accurately predict the timing and location of CI. More accurate forecasts of severe thunderstorms could potentially reduce the risks to people and property.
